newsitem.title: USA: Intel invests $14.75 mln in Avid.
newsitem.headline: Intel invests $14.75 mln in Avid.

text.p: Aiming to bring entertainment from the silver screen to consumers on the Intel platform, Intel Corp said Monday that it invested $14.75 million in Avid Technologies Inc.
The investment, in which Intel will purchase 1,552,632 newly issued shares of Avid valued at $9.50 a share based on the stock's Friday close, jumped 1-3/4 to 11-1/4.
The companies said in a joint news conference here that the investment was part of a strategic alliance supporting Avid's plans to offer video and audio editing products on the Intel architecture.

The Tewksbury, Mass.-based video and audio production equipment supplier has been challenged by the shift in the entertainment market away from traditional platforms, such as Apple Computer Inc's AAPL.O Macintosh systems.

William Miller, chairman and chief executive of Avid, said the company was still "actively working" on supporting Apple's new Rhapsody system software, which will include features from NeXT, the private company Apple acquired in December.
But he said he expects "a very powerful solution across a broad range of Intel-based platforms."
Miller said Avid already supports the Intel platform with several products, including MCXpress, NewsView and Elastic Reality - the latter providing warping and morphing capabilities.
Under the agreement, the two companies said they will work together to bring a broader range of additional digital content creation products to Intel-based PCs.
"We certainly want to work together to make the Intel platform just as good as it can possibly be," Miller said.
The deal, unveiled at Intel's "platforms for visual computing" conference here, is part of Intel's effort to launch itself into the world of Hollywood entertainment.

Craig Barrett, Intel's chief operating officer and president-elect, said the company expects its machines equipped with its processors to be used for authoring as well as playing multimedia content in coming years.

Miller said he anticipates this will extend beyond Hollywood, to businesses and eventually home users, who could, for example, post video recordings of a child's birthday party on the Internet for family to see.

"We intend to aggressively expand our capabilities on the Intel architecture," Miller said, adding the company will expand its distribution capabilities aimed at the use of Intel-based personal computers.
Miller declined to discuss specific product plans, but said interested parties should "stay tuned" for products.
Ronald Whittier, senior vice president and general manager of Intel's content group, said "Avid has a certain set of capabilities, customers and clients that are very important to Intel as well."
